Graphical abstract Iron titanate catalysts with various Fe/(Fe + Ti) ratios were prepared by sol-gel method and investigated in catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene (CB). The catalysts exhibited good activity and sulfation further promoted the performance in both activity and stability. Ti3+-oxygen vacancy (Vo) was determined with Raman, EPR and O2-TPD, while the generation mechanism of Ti3+-Vo was investigated by XPS and UV–vis. The structure-activity relationship was established between oxygen vacancies (Vo) and CB oxidation. The generation of Ti3+-Vo was attributed from the electron transfer from Fe3+ to Ti4+ in FeOTi structure as well as the incorporation of S4+ into surface lattice (for the sulfated catalyst). Moreover. the adsorption geometries of CB were comparatively studied. CB adsorbed on a pair of adjacent Lewis acid sites over the iron titanate catalysts through the Cl atom and the π cloud. CB of this adsorption type was highly activated and essentially contributed to the high activities. Keywords Chlorinated compounds Sulfated catalyst Iron titanate Oxygen vacancy Adsorption geometry 1 Introduction Chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs), acknowledged as an intractable class of air pollutants due to their chemical stability and severe harm to the environment as well as human beings [1], have caught wide attention in recent years. Current technologies for processing CVOCs include recycling technology and destruction technology, among which, catalytic combustion has been considered as the most ideal one due to its low cost, less secondary pollution and high efficiency [2–5].Generally, supported noble metal (such as Pt, Pd and Ru) catalysts exhibit good catalytic activity in CVOCs combustion [1,6–8]. However, for noble metals, there are some drawbacks critical and difficult to solve, such as high cost, high sensitivity to chlorine poisoning, sintering at high temperature, and loss of active ingredients during reaction [9]. While transition metal oxides show great potential as industrial catalysts for CVOCs oxidative decomposition due to their cheapness and chemical stability. The variety of transition metals also makes a rich diversity of structure and activity modulation. Currently, V-based catalytic systems like VOx/TiO2 have been widely studied and used in industrial applications [10–12]. Recent studies are mainly concentrating on catalytic systems based on Ce, Co, Mn, Fe and Ti [2,9,13–16], which are considered to be more environmental-friendly. TiO2 has been considered as an ideal catalytic material due to its innocuity, economy and stability. In particular, oxygen vacancies (Vo) on TiO2 surface have drawn considerable attention, which are considered important in catalytic oxidation reactions, chemical sensing, and photocatalysis [17]. The adsorption and diffusion mechanism of O2 on oxygen vacancies as well as oxygen-mediated surface structure over model TiO2 surface were demonstrated by means of time-resolved scanning tunneling microscopy and theoretical calculation [17–19]. With the oxides acting as reservoirs for oxygen, oxygen vacancies act as electron donors as well as adsorption sites for O2 and the charged O2* are expected to be very active [19]. As reported, TiO2 based catalytic systems such as Au/TiO2 showed a surprisingly high activity toward CO oxidation, which was considered to be attributed from activated O2* [20,21]. For other catalytic systems such as CeO2, oxygen vacancies were also found to be critical for catalytic oxidation processes like oxidation of typical VOCs [22,23]. Hence, the critical roles of oxygen vacancies in catalytic oxidation can be used as reference for oxidative decomposition of CVOCs. Fe-Ti mixed oxide, a cheap and efficient system for oxidative reaction, has been also reported to promote the generation of Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies [24,25]. On the other hand, sulfated metal oxides have exhibited enhanced activities for CVOCs oxidation, and the structure-activity relationship was established between strong acidity and oxidation activity of chloroalkanes, while the mechanism of promoted activities for aryl chlorides was not clear [4,16]. In this paper, iron titanate catalysts with various Fe/(Fe + Ti) ratios were prepared and doped by SO4 2−. The Ti3+-Vo was determined and the generation mechanism of Ti3+-Vo was investigated. The structure-activity relationship was established between oxygen vacancies and oxidation of CB. The adsorption geometries of CB as well as benzene (B) and ortho-dichlorobenzene (o-DCB) on the serial catalysts was also studied. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The iron titanate catalysts with various Fe/(Fe + Ti) ratios (0.05∼0.5) were synthesized by sol-gel method using isopropyl titanate and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O. In a typical experiment, with Fe/(Fe + Ti) ratio of 0.3, 10.0 g isopropyl titanate was dissolved in 16.2 g isopropanol and 6.1 g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O was separately dissolved in 32.4 g isopropanol. With stirring, the iron nitrate solution was added to the isopropyl titanate solution and a brown transparent gel was obtained afterwards. Then the gel was aged for 5 h and further dried at 110 °C for 12 h. After calcination at 400 °C in air for 4 h, a dark brown powder was obtained, denoted as 30FT. Sample 5FT, 15FT and 50FT were prepared by similar procedures, with Fe/(Fe + Ti) ratios of 0.05, 0.15 and 0.5, respectively. Sulfation of sample 30FT was conducted by wet impregnation using 2.0 mL of 0.5 M (NH4)2SO4 aqueous solution over per gram of dried hydroxide precursor (without calcination). While stirring, the obtained mixture was evaporated at 100 °C in oil bath and then dried at 110 °C. Calcination at 400 °C in air for 4 h was conducted afterwards and the obtained catalyst were denoted as 30FT-S. Si doped model catalyst was synthesized with the following procedures: In a typical experiment, with Fe: Ti: Si = 3: 7: 10, 10.0 g isopropyl titanate and 10.5 g tetraethyl orthosilicate were dissolved in 16.2 g isopropanol, while 15.0 g distilled water and 6.1 g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in 32.4 g isopropanol. With stirring, the iron nitrate solution was added dropwise to the organometallic salts solution and a brown transparent gel was obtained afterwards. Then the gel was aged, dried and calcinated as mentioned above. The obtained powder was denoted as 30FT/Si. With similar procedures of sulfation as above, sulfated 30FT/Si was denoted as 30FT/Si-S. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The characterization of as-synthesized catalysts by XRD, Nitrogen physisorption, ICP-OES, HRTEM, Raman, EPR, O2-TPD, UV–vis, XPS and in situ DRIFTS were previously described in our published papers [6,8]. 2.3 Activity measurement In a typical procedure, catalytic combustion tests over the synthesized catalysts were carried out at atmospheric pressure in a continuous flow micro-reactor made of a quartz tube with 4 mm in inner diameter. 200 mg catalyst with 40–60 mesh was loaded in the reactor bed. The feed stream flowed to the reactor at the rate of 100 mL/min, which was metered by a mass flow controller, and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV), of 30,000 mL g−1 h−1. The feed stream was composed of 1000 ppm CB and 10 % (vol) O2 balanced by N2 while CB was delivered by a syringe pump. The pipeline was electrically heated to ensure complete evaporation of CB. The reactor temperature was measured and controlled with two thermocouples located at the exit and bed of reactor. The reaction temperature was controlled in range of 100∼400 °C. Meanwhile, the organic reactant and products were analyzed on-line using GC (GC9790, FULI) equipped with a flame ionization detector and a KB-5−30 m ×0.32 mm ×0.50 μm capillary column. Cl2 was adsorbed by the effluent stream bubbling through a 0.0125 M NaOH solution, and its concentration was determined by titration method with ferrous ammonium sulfate with N, N-diethyl-p-phenylenediamine as an indicator [26]. 3 Results and disscusion 3.1 Physical structures The XRD patterns of the iron titanate samples with various Fe/(Fe + Ti) ratios are shown in Figure S1. For sample 5FT and 15FT with low iron content, diffraction peaks appear at 25.3°, 37.9°, 48.1°, 54.1°, 55.0°, 62.8°, 68.9°, 70.2° and 75.1°, which are attributed to the typical pattern of anatase (JCPDS NO. 21-1272). These diffraction peaks reduce in intensity and broaden as iron content increasing, and this can be interpreted as decrease of crystallinity, resulted from Fe3+ entering anatase lattice, in agreement with previous report [27]. On the pattern of sample 30FT, several new peaks at 35.9°, 41.3° and 54.6° appear, which match well to the known pattern of pseudorutile (Fe2Ti3O9, JCPDS NO. 47-1777), indicating a mixed phase of anatase and pseudorutile. As for 50FT, an amorphous phase can be observed. Besides, the crystalline phase of sulfated sample 30FT-S remains consistent with that of 30FT (Figure S1). Nitrogen physisorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the samples are shown in Figure S2 and the corresponding textural results are present in Table S1. There appear hysteresis loops for all the serial samples, demonstrating the existence of mesoporous structures, while the BET surface area and the BJH pore volume vary with iron content as a volcano curve, with maximum of 241 m2 g−1 and 0.252 mL g−1 for sample 30FT (decease to 199 m2 g−1 and 0.197 mL g-1 after sulfation), respectively. The ICP-OES results (Table S2) show that the Fe/(Fe + Ti) ratio of the serial iron titanate samples are in accord with preparation section, and the Sulphur loading of 30FT-S is determined to be 3.2 wt%. According to the overview of iron titanate samples with various iron content by TEM (Figure S3A, C, E, G), it can be seen that the serial samples all crystallized in form of nanocrystallites with diameter of 5∼10 nm. In the HRTEM images of the serial samples (Figure S3B, D, F, H), 5FT shows lattice fringes with interlayer spacing (d) of 0.350 nm, corresponding to (101) plane of anatase. The interlayer spacing (d) over 15FT are about 0.346 nm and 0.248 nm, identified as (101) plane of distorted anatase resulted from more Fe3+ incorporation and (001) plane of pseudorutile, respectively. For sample 30FT, nanocrystallites with hexagonal lattice fringes of pseudorutile (d = 0.248 and 0.143 nm, assigned to (001) and (110) plane of pseudorutile, respectively, seen in inset of Figure S3F) predominate, with nanocrystallites of Fe3+ doped anatase (d = 0.346 nm) in the minority. Alteration of crystalline phase is barely observed for sulfated sample 30FT-S (Figure S4A, B), corresponding to the XRD results. With iron content further increasing, lattice fringes with d = 0.346 nm and indistinct lattice fringes with d=0.270 nm can be observed, assigned to (101) plane of Fe3+ doped anatase and hematite, respectively, indicating existence of highly dispersed hematite phase (smaller than detection limit of XRD) on sample 50FT. 3.2 Determination of Ti3+-Vo The Raman spectra of the serial iron titanate samples as well as pure anatase and hematite samples are shown in Fig. 1 . There appear bands centered at 143 cm−1 (Eg), 197 cm−1 (Eg), 397 cm−1, 516 cm−1 (A1 g, B1 g), 639 cm-1 (Eg) for pure anatase sample and sample 5FT, 15FT demonstrate similar spectra to pure anatase, with slight but visible shift of band position, implying the formation of FeOTi structure. Moreover, three additional bands centered at 289 cm−1, 421 cm−1 and 695 cm−1 appear on 30FT (also partly visible on 15FT), which distantly resemble the characteristic bands of rutile TiO2 [8]. Therefore, combined with the results of XRD and HRTEM, these bands can be assigned to pseudorutile phase. Still, the characteristic bands of anatase TiO2 present on sample 30FT, with further shift of band position. For sample 50FT, the Raman spectrum is rather similar to that of pure hematite but lacks in bands at 284 cm−1 and 1305 cm−1 [16], indicating the existence of amorphous hematite on the catalyst surface, seeing that Raman spectra mainly reflect surface information. Moreover, in the region of 305∼350 cm−1 and 760∼920 cm−1, additional signals can be observed, with intensity in increasing order as follows: TiO2 ≈ 5FT < 15FT < 50FT < 30FT < 30FT-S. Jiang et al. reported broad bands centered at 316 cm−1 and 810 cm−1 appeared after hydrogenation of P25, which were assigned to second-order scattering and hydrogenation-induced structural, respectively [28]. Zheng et al. also reported a new band at 321.1 cm−1 observed in the surface-hydrogenated anatase TiO2 nanowire microspheres [29]. In this case, these two broad bands can be related to Ti3+-Vo and the band intensities semi-quantitatively reflect the Ti3+-Vo of the samples. The existence of Ti3+-Vo has been further verified by electron paramagnetic resonance spectra (EPR), as shown in Fig. 2 . As presented, pure TiO2 and Fe2O3 show no evident EPR signal compared to the mixed oxide samples. For sample 5FT, there are two signals with g = 4.30 and g = 1.99, which can be assigned to spin Fe3+ cations in a rhombic environment and substitutional spin Fe3+ cations in the anatase structure, respectively [24,30]. Note that the characteristic signal of Ti3+-Vo also appears at value of 1.99 [31,32]. However, the two signals with g = 1.99 can be distinguished clearly by line width since there appear obvious overlapping signals at g = 1.99 for sample 15FT and the emerging signal possess much broader line, which is typical for EPR signal of oxygen vacancy, as previously reported [24,33]. For the sample with higher iron content (30FT), signals at g = 4.30 and g = 1.99 (narrow line) disappear, and signal at g = 1.99 (broad line) becomes much intenser, indicating few isolated Fe3+ cation and much more Ti3+-Vo on 30FT. The EPR curve of 50FT is similar to that of 30FT, with evident decrease of signal intensity though, implying the further addition of iron inhibits the formation of Ti3+-Vo. Otherwise, sulfation of 30FT (30FT-S) further improves the content of Ti3+-Vo, consistent with the results in Raman spectra. To further study Vo on the catalyst surface, quantitatively, O2-TPD has been conducted, as shown in Fig. 3 . The O2-TPD curve of pure Fe2O3 presents no notable desorption peak, as expected, while there appear four desorption peaks for pure TiO2 through peak differentiating and imitating. The desorption peak centered below 100 °C can be attributed to oxygen of physisorption or weak chemisorption type and those centered about 135, 195 and 250 °C are contributed from the chemisorbed oxygen next to (not on) Vo of catalyst surface, such as O2 2−, O2-, O- [34,35]. The relative amounts of chemisorbed oxygen are calculated to be 0.3, 0.3, 0.7, 1.4, 2.5 and 0.8, respectively for TiO2, 5FT, 15FT, 30FT, 30FT-S and 50FT. Hence, with iron addition, the amounts of chemisorbed oxygen/Vo increase remarkably at first, with the maximum obtained on sample 30FT, and follow the order of TiO2 ≈ 5FT < 15FT < 50FT < 30FT < 30FT-S, in agreement with the Raman and EPR results. 3.3 Generation mechanisms of Ti3+-Vo Here, UV–vis spectra and XPS have been conducted to investigate the generation mechanism of Ti3+-Vo. As seen in UV–vis spectra (Fig. 4 ), there appear adsorptions centered at 361 nm, 554 nm, 673 nm for pure Fe2O3 and 344 nm for pure TiO2 in the region of 200∼800 nm, matched well with previous reports [27,36]. For the serial iron titanate samples, additional adsorptions centered at 406 nm and 500 nm can be observed and the former can be attributed to excitation of 3d electrons of Fe3+ to the TiO2 conduction band (charge transfer transition) resulted from FeOTi structure [30,32,37], which are not observably altered by sulfation. On the other hand, the latter adsorption at 500 nm become more apparent in samples with higher iron content, assigned to d-d transition of Fe3+ (2T2g → 2A2g, 2T1g) or the charge transition between interacting iron ions (Fe3+ + Fe3+ → Fe4+ + Fe2+) [30,32,37]. XPS method has analyzed the oxidation state of elements composing the samples by binding energy (B.E.), while all peak correlations were referenced to the C1s core level for CC/CH components at 284.8 eV. In Ti 2p core level spectra (Fig. 5 A), the binding energy of sample 5FT remain almost unchanged compared to pure TiO2, with Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 at 458.9 eV and 464.7 eV, respectively. With more incorporation of iron, Ti 2p binding energy of sample 15FT, 30FT and 50FT exhibit reduction by 0.1 eV, 0.3 eV and 0.2 eV, respectively. On the other hand, as seen in Fe 2p core level spectra (Fig. 5B), the Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 of pure Fe2O3 appear at 710.6 eV and 724.2 eV, respectively, while all the iron titanate samples exhibit higher binding energy by 0.9, 0.7, 0.5 and 0.1 eV separately for sample 5FT, 15FT, 30FT and 50FT. The results above demonstrate the electron transfer from Fe3+ to Ti4+ through FeOTi structure [27,38]. In this case, the electron cloud density of Fe3+ decreases more evidently by bonding to more Ti4+ (lower iron content), as implied by the upward shifts of Fe 2p binding energy. In the meantime, the electron cloud density of Ti4+ increases along with downward shift of Ti 2p binding energy, while the maximum shift is reached on sample 30FT instead of 50FT, revealing that the formation of hematite phase on 50FT, as revealed by HRTEM and Raman spectra, are accompanied with partial replacement of FeOTi by Fe-O-Fe. Further, it is proposed that the electron transfer in FeOTi could result in the formation of Ti3+-Vo. Here, based on the FWHM and asymmetry of Ti 2p peaks, characteristic peaks of Ti3+ can be identified through peak differentiating and imitating. As calculated, Ti3+/(Ti3++Ti4+) reach 7.2 %, 16.8 % and 9.2 % for sample 15FT, 30FT and 50FT, respectively, while trace of Ti3+ can be seen for pure TiO2 and 5FT, corresponding to the content of FeOTi structure (revealed by the crystalline phase composition) in the serial samples. Besides, sulfation of 30FT (30FT-S) significantly increase the binding energy for both Ti 2p and Fe 2p level by 0.8 eV, originated from the strong electron-withdrawing effect of sulfate group on the catalyst surface, and the content of Ti3+ is improved to 25.7 %. These results correspond well with the determination of Ti3+-Vo by Raman, EPR and O2-TPD. The generation mechanism of sulfation induced Ti3+-Vo could be intriguing. Here, the S 2p core level spectra of 30FT-S reveal co-existence of S6+ and S4+, as seen in Fig. 6 A. Moreover, after water wash, only slight reduction of S6+ is observed and S4+ remains unchanged. S4+ keeps stable even after the sample washed by strong base, while S6+ is nearly removed. Therefore, it is revealed that S4+ is incorporated into surface lattice while S6+ exist as surface sulfate species, and this can be further verified by Ar+ sputtering, which has etched the surface lattice and decrease of S4+ is observed consequentially. This phenomenon has been reported on S-doped TiO2, by Teruhisa Ohno et al. [39]. Generally, as electron with-drawing group, sulfate species on surface is not likely to facilitate the formation of Ti3+-Vo, and the incorporation of S4+ into surface lattice as substituting atoms for Ti4+ may be responsible instead. In addition, the presence of S4+ should be resulted from self-redox of the (NH4)2SO4 precursor. To sum up, Ti3+-Vo could be derived from the electron transfer from Fe3+ to Ti4+ in FeOTi structure, whose maximum presents on sample 30FT among the serial Ti-Fe mixed oxides, and Ti3+-Vo can be further promoted by sulfation, resulted from the incorporation of S4+ into the surface lattice. 3.4 Catalytic performance CB conversions over the serial iron titanate catalysts are demonstrated as function of temperatures, while DCB including o-DCB and p-DCB (para-dichlorobenzene) is the only organic by-products detected, as seen in Fig. 7 A, B. Pure TiO2 (anatase) and Fe2O3 (hematite) exhibit rather low activities towards CB oxidation, and incorporation of 5% Fe into TiO2 (5FT) makes few differences. The iron titanate catalysts with iron content of 15 % and 50 % (15FT and 50FT) perform higher activities with T50 at 376 and 356 °C, respectively. Remarkably, the catalytic performance is significantly promoted over catalyst 30FT, with T50 at 300 °C and T90 at 340 °C, which are further deceased to 243 °C and 292 °C after sulfation (30FT-S), respectively. To be more specific, the apparent reaction rates at 250 °C are estimated to be 0.007 (5FT), 0.011 (15FT), 0.030 (30FT), 0.018 (50FT) and 0.063 (30FT-S) μmol min−1 m-2, based on the mol number of transformed reactant per square meter per minute. Besides, the generation of DCB are inhibited evidently with iron addition, and the selectivities to DCB over 30FT and 30FT-S are consistently lower than 1%. Catalyst 30FT and 30FT-S also show rather high selectivities to CO2 (above 95 % within 200∼400 °C, seen in Fig. 7B), due to highly oxidative ability of the chemisorbed oxygen. Cl2 are not detected for all the serial samples below 400 °C, while Cl atoms are mostly converted into HCl and partly accumulate on the catalyst surface in longterm reaction processes. Further, the Cl accumulation on used catalyst 30FT and 30FT-S is determined through XPS (Figure S5) and the results indicate Cl accumulation is significantly lessened by sulfation (Brønsted acid is introduced to the catalyst surface by sulfation and Cl can be removed as HCl by Brønsted acid, as reported in our previous works) [6,16]. Moreover, after being etched by Ar+ (to remove S6+), catalyst 30FT-S Ar+ exhibit no evident loss of activity toward CB oxidation compared with before (Fig. 7A), indicating that the sulfate species together with the introduced Brønsted acid sites are not the main active centers for this reaction process. Here, the structure-activity relationship between Ti3+-Vo and CB oxidation is demonstrated with the reaction rate vs. the chemisorbed oxygen (quantified by O2-TPD and presented as a relative value), as presented in Fig. 8 , and a positive correlation can be observed for the iron titanate catalysts (5FT, 15FT, 30FT, 50FT) and 30FT-S in the region of 200∼300 °C. Further, for these samples, the normalized TOFs of CB over chemisorbed oxygen from 200 to 300 °C are calculated from the reaction rates normalized by the chemisorbed oxygen and show a linear correlation with the density of chemisorbed oxygen (calculated from chemisorbed oxygen normalized by SBET), as seen in Fig. 9 . Hence, it can be deduced that the metal oxides act as reservoirs for oxygen, and O2 diffusion may be the rate-limiting step in this oxidation process, as reported in TiO2 based catalytic systems for CO oxidation [19,20,40]. The catalytic stability tests for 30FT and 30FT-S have been carried out at reaction temperatures close to T50 and T90, as seen in Figure S6. Within 2800 min, the CB conversions over 30FT-S at 240 °C and 290 °C keep steady while those over 30FT reduce by 12 % and 24 % at 310 °C and 350 °C, respectively. The results above imply the deactivation of catalyst 30FT are caused by Cl poisoning, which can be resisted by the sulfated catalyst to a large extent, and therefore catalyst 30FT-S can be considered to be very potential for industrial applications. Besides, the effect of water is investigated with wet feeding containing 5% water (vol) over these two catalysts (Figure S7). The results show that the negative effect of water for CB conversion mainly occur at temperatures lower than 250 °C, and activities of the catalysts at higher temperatures are very close to those under dry feeding, revealing the strong water resistence. Here, the negative effect of wet feeding below 250 °C can be attributed from the competitive adsorption between water and CB molecules. In addition, conversion curves of B and o-DCB combustion over 30FT as well as 30FT-S are presented in Figure S8. As presented, activities of the both catalysts for o-DCB are lower to those for CB, with the conversion curves shifting to higher temperature by 20∼30 °C and the apparent reaction rates at 250 °C to be 0.014 and 0.040 μmol min−1 m-2, separately for 30FT and 30FT-S. Still, extremely low chlorination activities for o-DCB have been be observed, with trace of TCB detected (not shown). However, the activities for B is unexpectedly lower than those for CB, with T50 and T90 of 273 and 330 °C for 30FT-S, 316 and 362 °C for 30FT, respectively, considering that B is oxidized more easily owing to higher density of its π cloud. Here, the apparent activation energies (Ea) for B, CB and o-DCB over catalyst 30FT-S were determined with 95 % confidence limits using the rate dependence on the temperature in the conversion section below 20 %, based on Arrhenius equation, and the results appear to be 55.7, 37.1 and 59.6 kJ mol-1, respectively (Figure S9). The Ea for CB is significantly lower than those of B and o-DCB, which explain the high activity for CB oxidation and the unexpectedly low activity for B oxidation to some extent, while this would be further discussed below. In addition, the reaction rates and Ea from literatures are shown in Table S3 for comparison. 3.5 In situ DRIFT spectra The in situ DRIFT spectra for CB adsorption/oxidation at different temperatures (100∼350 °C) over catalyst 30FT and 30FT-S pre-treated in 10 % O2-Ar at 400 °C for 1 h, were recorded at 100 °C in Ar/10 % O2-Ar, respectively. The spectra for CB adsorption and oxidation within 1800∼1100 cm−1 over 30FT (Figure S10A and B) are almost identical, except for higher intensity in the latter. The bands for adsorbed CB appear at 1579, 1478 and 1445 cm−1. The bands between 1500∼1565 cm−1 together with bands at 1431, 1414, 1379, 1360 and 1309 cm−1 can be attributed to carboxylate species, like formate (1561, 1379 and 1360 cm−1), acetate (1548, 1414 cm−1) and maleate (1512, 1431 and 1309 cm−1) [8,14]. In contrast, the spectra for CB adsorption and oxidation over 30FT-S exhibit intenser and broader bands. In both the spectra, the appearance of the broad band at 1660 cm−1 and the band at 1421 cm−1 indicates the formation of acetaldehyde, which arises from Brønsted acid sites, as previously reported [14]. In the spectra of CB oxidation, disappearance of the bands at 1379, 1360 and 1309 cm−1 along with emergence of the bands at 1611, 1330 and 1218 cm−1 for carbonate of bidentate type [41] demonstrate the carboxylate are further oxidized to carbonate in the presence of gaseous oxygen. The fact that reaction intermediates are formed without gaseous oxygen implies that the absorbed CB molecules are attacked by surface oxygen to form carboxylate as well as carbonate, and the surface oxygen can be replenished from gas phase in oxidative feeding, resulting in significantly higher intensities of the reaction intermediates. Since the high stabilities of Ti-O and Fe-O, involvement of lattice oxygen could be excluded and the “surface oxygen” should be attributed to chemisorbed oxygen next to surface Vo, such as O2 2-, O2-, O-. The in situ DRIFT spectra in the region of 2100∼1700 cm−1 for CB adsorption at 150 °C are presented in Fig. 10 . Here, the discussion will be focused on the CH out of plane deformation modes, and the corresponding bands of standard material (liquid) are shown in Table 1 . As demonstrated, the characteristic bands for the CH out of plane deformation modes over catalyst 30FT and 30FT-S are almost identical. There appear bands at 1965, 1889, 1818 cm−1 for CB, which are remarkably higher in wavenumber than the those of liquid CB (1939, 1860 and 1788 cm−1). The upward shift of CH out of plane deformation modes can be interpreted as evidence of π-type adsorption, where the interaction occurs through the aromatic electron cloud of aromatic compounds on electron withdrawing centers (Lewis acid) of metal oxides, while no shift or downward shift imply the “vertical” adsorption geometry of aromatics through substituents [42,43]. As a comparative study, the spectra of in situ adsorption for B and o-DCB under the same conditions have been collected and different phenomena can be observed (Fig. 10). For o-DCB over both 30FT and 30FT-S, identical bands at 1951, 1916 and 1793 cm−1 can be observed, with no evident shift from the standard spectra (1951, 1915, 1792 cm-1), indicating o-DCB adsorbs “vertically” on the catalyst surface through a Cl atom [43]. Here, the different adsorption geometry for o-DCB could be resulted from the lower density of π-type clouds, compared to CB. As for B adsorption, the spectra for 30FT and 30FT-S with bands at 1972 and 1830 cm−1 also exhibit upward shift compared to standard spectra (1961, 1815 cm-1), while this shift is evidently lower compared to the case of CB, implying a π-type adsorption geometry somehow different from that of CB. In consideration of the unexpectedly low activities for B oxidation, it is deduced that CB adsorbs on a pair of adjacent Lewis acid sites, through the π electron cloud and the Cl atom, while B adsorbs on a single Lewis acid site through the π electron cloud. The carbonium ion generated from rupture of the C-Cl bond (which is easy when Cl is attached to Lewis acid) is more active than B, resulting in the lower activity for B compared to CB. Hence, the remarkable differences of Ea between B, CB and o-DCB should mostly be attributed from the different geometries. To be more intuitive, the graphic illustration of the adsorption geometries for B, CB and o-DCB is shown in Fig. 11 A and the reaction pathway of CB oxidation over the iron titanate catalysts is shown in Scheme 1 . 3.6 Si doped model catalysts To further verify the results mentioned above, model catalyst 30FT/Si was prepared by incorporation of Si into Ti-Fe complex with atomic radio of Fe: Ti: Si = 3: 7: 10, aiming for replacing FeOTi with FeOSiOTi structure. With similar method of sulfation, 30FT/Si-S was also prepared. The structure of the model catalysts is characterized by Nitrogen physisorption, XRD, ICP-OES, HRTEM, Raman, XPS and vis-UV. Catalyst 30FT/Si and 30FT/Si-S, with BET surface area of 405 and 395 m2/g, respectively, both show identical XRD patterns (Figure S1) attributed to anatase and pseudorutile, which are consistent with sample 30FT but decrease in crystallinity. The ICP-OES results (Table S2) indicate that the element composition (Fe, Ti and Si) of these two catalysts are in accord with the preparation section, and the Sulphur loading of 30FT/Si-S is determined to be 3.0 wt%, which is close to that of 30FT-S. In Raman spectra (Fig. 1), 30FT/Si show homologous phase characteristics as sample 30FT, with distinct band shift as evidence of Si incorporation into lattice, and the phase characteristics are not affected by sulfation, in agreement with the XRD results. The decease of crystallinity and the shifts of Raman bands imply the incorporation of Si into FeOTi lattice. Moreover, the HRTEM image of 30FT/Si (Figure S4C) show similar micromorphology as 30FT, while the lattice fringes are distorted with the interlayer spacing (d) of anatase nanocrystallites changed to 0.310 nm and the hexagonal lattice of pseudorutile severely deformed as presented in Figure S4D. This also indicates the incorporation of Si into the lattice of Fe-doped anatase and pseudorutile. The Ti 2p and Fe 2p core level spectra of 30FT/Si (Figure S11A, B) show much less shifts of bind energy from pure TiO2 and Fe2O3 (-0.1 eV and +0.1 eV, respectively), compared with those of 30FT (-0.3 eV and +0.5 eV, respectively). This indicates the electron transport from Fe3+ to Ti4+ is significantly inhibited, further implying the FeOTi structure is replaced by FeOSiOTi after Si incorporation. As expected, for 30FT/Si, there is approximately 4.3 % of Ti3+ identified through peak differentiating and imitating of Ti 2p peaks, much less than that for 30FT (16.8 %). On the other hand, unlike 30FT, sulfation of 30FT/Si (Figure S11A) barely improves the radio of Ti3+, while this could originate from infeasibility of S4+ incorporation into FeOSiOTi structure, as demonstrated by S 2p spectra of fresh and base-washed 30FT/Si-S (Fig. 7B). The S2p signal of fresh sample 30FT/Si-S is almost eliminated after washed by strong base and the signal of S4+ in lattice is barely observed, which is different from the case of sample 30FT-S. In the spectra of vis-UV (Figure S12), 30FT/Si and 30FT/Si-S exhibit additional adsorption at 298 nm of Si-O and remarkably lower adsorption at 406 nm and 500 nm of electron transport from Fe3+ to Ti4+ and Fe3+ to Fe3+, respectively, in contrast to those of 30FT, demonstrating a higher degree of isolation for Fe3+ and Ti4+ in 30FT/Si and verifying the existence of FeOSiOTi structure. Likewise, Ti3+-Vo of Si-Ti-Fe catalysts is characterized by Raman (Fig. 1), EPR (Fig. 2) and O2-TPD (Figure S13). As demonstrated, 30FT/Si exhibits significantly lower EPR and O2-TPD signals, together with Raman bands in the region of 305∼350 cm−1 and 760∼920 cm-1 with much lower intensity, compared to those for 30FT, and promotion can be hardly observed after sulfation (30FT/Si-S). More importantly, FeOSiOTi structure physically and essentially eliminates the possibility of the “π-Cl∼double acid” type adsorption due to segregation of adjacent acid sites by Si and size limit of CB molecules. The in situ reaction FT-IR spectra in the region of 2100∼1700 cm−1 over 30FT/Si, presented in Fig. 10, show the out of plane C–H deformation modes of CB at 1952, 1873 and 1798 cm−1, which reveal upward band shift from the bands of liquid CB, but the band shift is evidently lower in comparison with the case of sample 30FT and 30FT-S. In contrast, the bands of B and o-DCB over 30FT/Si exhibit no change in band position from those over 30FT and 30FT-S. Therefore, this downward band shift can be interpreted as the change of adsorption geometry for CB from “π-Cl∼double acid” into “π∼single acid” type (as illustrated in Fig. 11B) due to FeOSiOTi structure, while the adsorption geometries over single acid sites for B and o-DCB remain uninfluenced. These results match well with expectation and therefore verify the generation mechanism of Ti3+-Vo and the adsorption geometries of reactants we proposed. In Fig. 7A, rather low activities of 30FT/Si and 30FT/Si-S for CB oxidation can be observed, with extremely low apparent reaction rates at 250 °C of 0.0028 and 0.0035 μmol min−1 m-2, respectively. On the other hand, it is apparent that 30FT/Si and 30FT/Si-S are incoherent for the structure-activity relationship shown in Fig. 8 and Fig. 9, due to the different adsorption geometry for Si doped catalysts. The apparent activation energies (Ea) for CB were determined with 95 % confidence limits using the rate dependence on the temperature in the conversion section below 20 %, based on Arrhenius equation, which appear at 37.1, 44.0 and 70.0 kJ mol-1 for 30FT-S, 30FT and 30FT/Si, respectively (Figure S14). The results reveal activation of the “π-Cl∼double acid” type CB is much easier than that of “π∼single acid” type (since the C-Cl bond is unlikely broken first for the latter type and activation of the passivated aryl ring of CB is hard), and it would be further promoted with higher density of Vo/chemisorbed oxygen. For the oxidation process of B and o-DCB, the model catalyst exhibit activities comparable to those over catalyst 30FT (shown in Figure S8). The apparent activation energies for B and o-DCB over catalyst 30FT and 30FT/Si are also calculated with the same method as above and the results appear to be 59.3, 63.2 kJ mol-1 for B and 63.6, 67.9 kJ mol-1 for o-DCB respectively (Figure S15), which show rather small differences between these two catalysts, in opposite to the case of CB (44.0 and 70.0 kJ mol-1, respectively), verifying the adsorption geometries being unchanged for B and o-DCB over FeOTi and FeOSiOTi. 3.7 Discussion on contribution of acidity The adsorption performance is highly depended on the acidity of catalysts as known and therefore the acidity of the catalysts should also be considered. The acidity of the serial catalysts and the model catalysts is determined by NH3-TPD with the temperature rising from 100 °C to the calcination temperature (400 °C), shown in Figure S16. The NH3-TPD curves are divided into three ranges as weak (100∼200 °C), moderate (200∼300 °C) and strong acid (300∼400 °C). Based on the work curve of peak area vs ammonia content, the acidity of samples is quantified and the results were shown in Table S4. Strong acid sites are generally considered as the active sites for adsorption of chlorinated molecules [2,7,16]. Accordingly, Figure S17 is demonstrated with the reaction rate vs. the strong acid, and no reasonable correlation can be observed. Hence, the adsorption step of CB molecules on the surface acid sites is unlikely be the rate-limiting step in the reaction process, which should be considered as O2 diffusion instead, corresponding to the discussion above. 4 Conclusions Iron titanate catalysts with various iron content (5FT, 15FT, 30FT and 50FT) were prepared by sol-gel method and sulfation of 30FT (30FT-S) was conducted by wet impregnation. The serial catalysts showed good activities for CB oxidation, in the order of 5FT < 15FT < 50FT < 30FT < 30FT-S. The sulfated catalyst 30FT-S exhibited extremely good activity with apparent reaction rate of 0.063 μmol min−1 m-2 at 250 °C and much enhanced stability as well as water resistence. Consistent results of Raman, EPR and O2-TPD in determining Ti3+-Vo were observed and the Ti3+-Vo contents were ordered as 5FT < 15FT < 50FT < 30FT < 30FT-S as well. The structure-activity relationship was established between the chemisorbed oxygen (the chemisorbed O2 next to the oxygen vacancies) and the reaction rates of CB oxidation. The TOFs of CB are linearly correlated to the density of oxygen vacancies/chemisorbed oxygen. Hence, O2 diffusion may be the rate-limiting step for this oxidation process. The generation of Ti3+-Vo over the serial catalysts, investigated by XPS and UV–vis, was considered to be attributed from the electron transfer from Fe3+ to Ti4+ in FeOTi structure as well as the incorporation of S4+ into surface lattice (for the sulfated catalyst), verified by the results for the Si doped model catalysts. In situ DRIFT spectra for CB adsorption and oxidation over the iron titanate catalysts revealed that the adsorbed CB was attacked by chemisorbed oxygen to form carboxylate species (formate, acetate, maleate, etc.) and further oxidized to carbonate by gaseous oxygen. Moreover, the out of plane C–H deformation modes of B/CB/o-DCB over the iron titanate catalysts demonstrated different adsorption geometries for B (“π∼single acid”), CB (“π-Cl∼double acid”) and o-DCB (“vertical adsorption”). As expected, the adsorption geometry for CB over the Si doped model catalysts turned to be “π∼single acid” type due to segregation of adjacent acid sites by Si. The apparent activation energies (Ea) for CB over 30FT-S, 30FT, and 30FT/Si were calculated to be 37.1, 44.0 and 70.0 kJ mol−1, respectively, indicating that activation of the “π-Cl∼double acid” type CB is much easier than that of “π∼single acid” type, and it would be further promoted with higher density of oxygen vacancies/chemisorbed oxygen. coredata.dc:description: Iron titanate catalysts with various Fe/(Fe + Ti) ratios were prepared by sol-gel method and investigated in catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene (CB). The catalysts exhibited good activity and sulfation further promoted the performance in both activity and stability. Ti3+-oxygen vacancy (Vo) was determined with Raman, EPR and O2-TPD, while the generation mechanism of Ti3+-Vo was investigated by XPS and UV–vis. The structure-activity relationship was established between oxygen vacancies (Vo) and CB oxidation. The generation of Ti3+-Vo was attributed from the electron transfer from Fe3+ to Ti4+ in FeOTi structure as well as the incorporation of S4+ into surface lattice (for the sulfated catalyst). Moreover. the adsorption geometries of CB were comparatively studied. CB adsorbed on a pair of adjacent Lewis acid sites over the iron titanate catalysts through the Cl atom and the π cloud. CB of this adsorption type was highly activated and essentially contributed to the high activities.
coredata.dc:title: Oxidative decomposition of chlorobenzene over iron titanate catalysts: The critical roles of oxygen vacancies and adsorption geometries
